item.title: Our boy, The Adjuster...
item.description: Yes, our boy's New York State trial is expected to begin first, where he pleaded not guilty to murder charges including terrorism counts (though terrorism charges were later dismissed). He also pleaded not guilty to federal charges in April 2025, where verminous prosecutors are seeking the death penalty. His attorneys have raised concerns about a fair trial, citing DOJ employees' social media activity and arguing Mangione has been treated as a "political pawn". In September 2025, a judge dismissed the state terrorism charges, finding insufficient evidence that Mangione intended to terrorize the public, though he still faces second-degree murder charges. A federal status conference is scheduled for January 9, 2026, with pretrial motions and discovery ongoing. His Pennsylvania case is on hold until the New York proceedings conclude.
item.dc:creator: NChomsky

item.title: "Woman with the Handbag". Statue about hitting Nazis
item.description:
This is a Swedish statue commemorating when Danuta Danielsson hit a marching neo-Nazi with her purse on April 14, 1985. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Woman_with_the_Handbag
In February of 2015 Swedish artist Susanna Arwin proposed creating this statue in Växjö, Sweden. However, the local council decided against erecting it because they felt it promoted violence, and because Danielsson's surviving family did not like the idea of her being memorialized in such a manner. In response, people around Sweden protested by adding handbags to statues. In September of that year a Swedish hotel entrepreneur announced that he had purchased the statue with the intention of donating it to the municipality of Varberg, Sweden. It was then put on display at Varberg Fortress. The following year the Varberg board of culture voted not to accept the donation and the statue was moved to the garden of Lasse Diding's Villa Wäring, with a second statue being erected in Alingsås, Sweden.

26 Imgur Creator Spotlight: @tranquilsquid made cute kitty ornaments! Check them out.
27 Man Tax: Lucien Laviscount
“Dare to love yourself as if you were a rainbow with gold at both ends.” - Aberjhani I try to keep my posts "good vibe zones". So, instead of finding the one thing in here you don't like and commenting only on that, also comment about something you DID like. Balance the negativity. Love you long time. So, I made a discord server. It's a relaxed environment where you can take/donate memes to the cause, play trivia twice a week, chat about lots of topics or about nothing at all. We also have Jack Box game night and are setting up movie night! Very laid back/relaxed vibe. Come hang with us. https://discord.gg/AWFV7FT3RQ I'm also on the imgcat server for updates & fun: https://discord.gg/TpjD37jgJ9 ***Also if you miss abbiistabbii's discord community good news! You can now find it here https://discord.gg/6nrrXJQa - where everyone's reconnecting, shitposting, and hanging out again*** https://ko-fi.com/mememuseumcurator Unable to work and pretty destitute. Feel free to leave me a tip. Those that have, y'all are the bee's knees. You've helped me so much. ***Tag me if you see an artist/creator you like whose work isn't getting seen as much as it should be! Or if you are an artist/creator and want me to post something of yours, DM me!

item.title: Look who got adopted today!!
item.description:
Foster kitten Mario got snapped up first thing this morning!
And Stratus and Luigi got adopted together!! This is perfect, because both of them really needed to be with another kitten. Mario will do just fine by himself, but these two really need a buddy. A banner day for my foster kittens!

item.title: Why Americans need unions.
item.description:
Things to think about during a job interview . . .
Know your worth. If you have special skills, don't use them if pay is not commensuratal to the skills needed.
Always work your wage. If you are asked to do something not in your job description, it should be compensated properly.
Always work your wage. A one-off is fine, but if it continues every day, you're being paid the same for doing more work. Don't fall into this trap. Businesses justify this behavior as they downsize without having proper employment practices.
Wage theft costs the American workers about $50,000,000,000 (fifty billion dollars) a year. Tips are not to be split with management.
Wage theft costs the American workers about $50,000,000,000 (fifty billion dollars) a year.
Wage theft costs the American workers about $50,000,000,000 (fifty billion dollars) a year.
Wage theft costs the American workers about $50,000,000,000 (fifty billion dollars) a year. Being called in to work when you're off, especially on vacation, is wrong and should be compensated accordingly... or ot done at all.
At work and higher power
The toxic work place.
Wage theft costs the American workers about $50,000,000,000 (fifty billion dollars) a year. Unless you are being paid to be on call, your time away from work is your ownm
Vacation time: Always keep your vacation approval on file at home. If something like this occurs, your ass is covered.
Always cover you ass.
The toxic workplace
CYA. Even in a 2-party consent state, as long as your recording isn't used in a court of law, you can use it outside of the courts. In a situation like this, if the supervisor should choose to sue. They have to produce the recording.
Resignation. In the US, every state has an "At Will" law. Unless you have a union contract stating this, you can quit at any time without notice.
Resignation: when you do give a 2-week notice and they terminate you, you do have some rights. In A situation like this, always ask for your termination in writing. It makes it easier to file for unemployment.
Resignations:
Just a minor change in private employment ?

item.title: Have some squirrels in these trying times.
item.description:
This squirrel ate some fermented fruit in the bowl and is now drunk. It's not uncommon for squirrels to get drunk off fermented fruit during the winter.
According to the owner of this camera, this squirrel keeps knocking the camera out of alignment trying to place stuff on top of it. In this video you can see the squirrel trying to hide a slice of pizza on top of the camera.

item.title: The Big Ugly Antique Register Rescue Update #7: FINISHED!
item.description:
Gooooooood mornin', Usersub! It's that time of the weekend again, and that means yet another progress update on the restoration-slash-resuscitation of this 1912 National Cash Register! Best of all, it's the last update for this project because it's finished!! For context, I broke ground on this absolute mess of a register two months ago. Seriously, first post, back when I thought this would be a quick few weeks of cleaning and oiling: https://imgur.com/gallery/AbmpY0s Oh, those were more innocent times... Anyway, onto the final leg of this hike!
First up, as you probably noticed in the thumbnail, I got the price flags sorted and back in their respective slots. Really easy step at this point, just arrange by denomination and drop 'em in. The only bit that can get tricky if you don't pay attention is making sure they're layered correctly. Each flag is bent forward or back to make room for their neighbors, and mixing them up is a great way to jam a machine with a single keypress. :) For the condition this cash register was in, the flags are still in excellent shape. No chips, no big stains or discolorations. The paint was originally white in 1912, and has deepened to a softer cream over the last century from cigarette smoke.
I actually had to do a double-take when I went to go put the drawer in. This project has taken so much time that I actually forgot that I never cleaned it out. Luckily, the coin cups look to be more dusty and dirty than anything else. The original lacquer looked pretty intact where the wood wasn't eroded by coins, so I opted to take the gentle approach and just wash it out.
If you've never scrubbed these out with cracked fingertips, you've never experienced fun before. >_<'
Another shot of the drawer in its original state.
And the cleaned out result. There's a little leftover grit stuck under the dividers, but I see no reason to do a teardown for something as minor as that. The cups and trays cleaned up nicely with a 1:10 mix of concentrated wood soap and water. One thing I really like about doing gentler restorations of these cash drawers is that you end up retaining the grooves worn into the wood by 100+ years of coins being pulled up the slope by countless clerks. Even when the register is shiny and rebuilt, there's still a visible marker of its history readily available inside.
With the cash drawer done, all that remains before the final rebuild is cleaning off the crud built up on the glass and marble pieces. When I first bought it back in April, the seller had made an effort to crop out a certain busted-up attachment to the top glass that left all the sticky remnants you can see here.
I had to go digging into my phone for a photo with that add-on included. Ah, yes, the coveted broken Busch beer desk lamp, held on with immensely powerful double-sided sticky tape, glue, and a cardboard pad. The finest of accessories. Frankly I'm amazed I didn't shatter the pane pulling this stupid thing off.
Luckily, I was able to get that schmutz off with a liberal application of Goo-Gone. Again, I'm really impressed with how well preserved the panes and marble shelf are. Even the tiny windows for the dust cover, which are basically just microscope slides in thickness, are chip-free! And with that done, I've got nothing left to wash up or prep! Time for FINAL REASSEMBLY!
Please ignore any other cash register parts you may notice in the background. <_< Those don't exist yet. Anyway, two months of intense work later it's finally reassembly day! Time to bust out the screws and hope I don't do something stupid!
First up, gotta set this big heavy thing into that wood base I was working on last month! Small benefit of having this restoration take so long is that the tung oil is nice and cured, and the wood feels smooth as butter.
The first panel to go on is the rear one since it supplies the structural support for the sides. I'd debated spending the weekend running each panel through the polishing wheel to even out the finish, but in the end I decided not to chase perfection. This was a register that was on life support when I found it, and I'm more than satisfied to see it back in clean, working condition.
The side panels look a fair bit better, and as I'm putting it back together I'm noticing that the stain I used for the wooden base might be just a little darker than I personally would have liked. Granted, I didn't know the final rebuild would have this much contrast, but in the future I think I'll err on lighter shades of stain and work my way down to darker tones if I think it's needed. Still, I *love* the grain.
And of course, some of the color is due to my amateur photography. Also, ignore that other register. It's not there. I'm definitely not crowded on this end of the table either. Anyhow, with both side panels fitted to the base, I can start attaching the cross supports!
I really love the design of this crosspiece. Instead of having to maneuver four big bolts underneath it and risk dropping them into the mechanics below, there are four studs to support it while I screw it down through the side panels. Why they went to the more annoying design later on is anyone's guess. This crosspiece not only displays the serial number badge for the register, but it's what the dust cover lid screws onto. Also keep ignoring that thing in the background.
A little hard to see, but I've attached the brass plated crossbar over the drawer box as well as a simple iron rod just behind the lever assembly.
That metal bar is what this lever come screws down onto, which keeps each lever spaced evenly and prevents them from twisting. The narrow piece with the row of hobnails is a dust skirt that keeps coins and bills from slipping behind the coin shelf and getting lost in the machine. Also, bonus points for being able to use the original marble coin shelf! Half the time these are cracked in several places or are broken at the corners, leaving jagged shards requiring a full replacement. I love that this one survived and in such great condition.
With the paneling done, the dust cover goes on next. Despite how much I worked at cleaning this off, you can clearly see all of the strike marks left by smokers who used the rough texture to light their matches. The black residue left behind is ridiculously stubborn to get out, and even when its gone there's discolored metal beneath it that I haven't quite worked out a formula for correcting short of a completely new layer of nickel, or paint. Still, it's history from a thankfully bygone era when everyone and their kids smoked, and there's something to be said about leaving those marks intact.
Of course, no restoration would be complete if I didn't forget to do something only to realize it during the rebuild. I'd set this lid counter aside for cleaning when I did the disassembly and completely missed it until now. Thankfully, all it needs is a few minutes of scrubbing.
Easy peasy!
And lemon squeezy! I had to use some new brass screws to tighten it down, since almost half of the originals were missing from this machine. Gotta love it when people take something apart lose half the fastners! :D
At least they kept the originals for the serial plate!
With the lid reassembled and the last of the extraneous bits attached, I wrap up the main body of the register by reinstalling the glass and tightening down the end caps that hold the panes in place. Those open screw holes are mounting points for a top sign that this register didn't come with, and I'm noooot quite ready to drop $300+ on one when the majority are reproductions masquerading as originals. No spanks. :)
Now all that's left is to slide in the cash drawer...
...and screw in the front plate! For kicks and giggles, I decided to stick with the original solid nickel plate that the register came to me with and screw it down with brass wood screws to tie in the rest of the register. It looks neat, but I'm going to make a trip to the hardware store for some silver replacements so it stops ticking away at my OCD.
Oh, hey, speaking of things I'm forgetting to do, these keys look kinda really a lot nasty. Luckily, cleaning them up is just a matter of hitting them with some isopropyl alcohol until the built up layer of finger grime softens up and using a nylon brush to scrape it out. It takes a half hour or so to get every key cleaned up, but it's well worth the time.
Oddly, none of the keys have their original cellophane layers to protect the decals beneath. Granted, it's not much of an issue since the register won't be seeing any more of the high-traffic wear and tear it would have gotten were it in use in a business setting, but it does make me wonder why someone would take them out. My focus, however, is on that final empty key. Back when I started the restoration I jotted up a list of replacement parts and tools I expected to need for the project, and a bunch of you chipped in to cover some of those costs including the decal for that empty key. It's small, but this ain't going to be finished without it!
Et voila! Cleaned up and with a complete set once more!
With two months of work, several moments of abject panic, and a whole mountain of self-doubt and inexperience firmly behind me, I can happily declare this restoration COMPLETE.
Not only is it squeaky clean and lead-free, it's easily one of the smoothest operating cash registers I've come out the other end of a restoration with. There's no more sticking, no needing to put my weight into the levers to get them to work, and best of all it rings loud and clear with every press of a key.
Considering how close this one came to becoming a dusty old scrap machine to be picked apart for the occasional knob, key ring, or panel, I'm over the moon with how well it came out the other side!
Is it perfect? Nope! Does it matter to me? Nope again! Because I know when I finally decide to sell this to the next owner, they're going to be able to feel confident that this register has at least another 113 years of life in it again. ^_^
Oh, and I totally didn't forget to screw this back on. Extra credit for the original embossing surviving all those decades of neglect!
Of course, the obligatory proof-of-life ringy-dingy. :)
And one last bonus historical treat to really emphasize how ubiquitous these cash registers were in a pre-computerized era. They were centerpieces to the establishments which purchased them, even as fashions changed. Only after digital registers became affordable did these mechanical masterpieces finally make their way off the clerk's desk and into homes, barns, storage sheds, and scrapyards.
And the beauty of this hobby is that even though these machines might look broken down, disheveled, and too picked apart to be worth the effort, they're still very much worth the struggle.
Because the can still wind up looking like this. ^_^
If you want to directly contribute toward making these restorations possible, please consider chipping in on Kofi! https://ko-fi.com/elbowdeepinahorse Every little bit, whether it's $5 or $50, gets put toward purchasing the gloves, brushes, wood stains, polishing supplies, replacement parts, and all the less predictable costs needed to make these restorations possible. Without you, I wouldn't be able to do a tenth of this. Thank you all so much. <3
Holy heck. Time to crack open a can of Dr. Pepper and take a nap!! Thanks for reading, everyone! (Artist: RocketLawnchair)
item.dc:creator: ElbowDeepInAHorse
